content: Amendments to the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act of 2000. Amendments to the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act of 2000 include changing "microentrepreneurs" to "microenterprise households", updating "microfinance policy" to "microenterprise policy", and ensuring that at least 50 percent of all microenterprise assistance is targeted to the very poor. Definitions in the Act are also amended. Amendments to the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act of 2000 redefine "very poor" as individuals living below the national poverty line or on less than $1 per day. Amendments are made to the Micro- and Small Enterprise Development Credits Program under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. Amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 include changing the focus from developing enterprises of the poor to improving access to financial services and supporting microenterprises. The President is authorized to provide assistance for increasing financial services for microenterprise households through loans, guarantees, and training programs for microfinance institutions. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to focus on improving access to financial services for microenterprise households through loans, guarantees, and training programs for microfinance institutions. Amendments include changing the terminology from "credit institutions" to "microfinance institutions" and from "micro- and small enterprises" to "microenterprise households." The aim is to enhance financial literacy and enterprise management to improve quality of life. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to focus on improving access to financial services for microenterprise households through loans, guarantees, and training programs for microfinance institutions. Amendments include changing terminology and availability of funds for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to enhance microenterprise development credits and make amendments to the microenterprise development grant assistance program. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to emphasize the importance of access to financial services and the development of microenterprises in developing countries. This includes providing credit, savings, training, technical assistance, and other services to support microenterprise growth. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to target both rural and urban poor populations in developing countries through microenterprise programs. Amendments include changing terminology from "entrepreneurs" to "clients" and emphasizing the provision of financial services to poor entrepreneurs. The monitoring system is also revised to enhance support for microenterprise development. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to target rural and urban poor populations in developing countries through microenterprise programs. Amendments include adopting poverty assessment tools to identify the very poor and ensure they receive necessary financial assistance. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development will develop and certify poverty measurement methods in consultation with relevant organizations. The United States Agency for International Development will develop low-cost methods to assess poverty levels of clients, field-test and certify approved methods by October 1, 2004, for microenterprise institutions to assist the very poor. The Administrator will require organizations seeking microenterprise assistance to use certified methods to determine and report poverty levels of clients. Additionally, the level of assistance will increase to $175,000,000 for fiscal year 2003 and $200,000,000 for fiscal year 2004. The definition of "very poor" includes individuals living in the bottom 50 percent below the national poverty line. The definition of "very poor" includes individuals living below the national poverty line or on less than $1 per day. SEC. 4. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development must submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2005, detailing the poverty assessment procedures used with partners. Starting from fiscal year 2006, annual reports must document the agency's compliance with the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act by showing the percentage of resources allocated to the very poor based on certified methods. The report to Congress must detail the poverty assessment procedures and the number of very poor reached using certified methods.
